Common denominator when adding/subtracting fractions is a least common multiple(lcm[b, d]) of b and d. You culd also multiply both fractions by a  fraction of bd / bd that is 1 and so not changing neither of two fractions that add up: a/b + c/d                                                                                // adding fractions b * d                                                                                        // b * d is a common multiple of b and d b * d/b * d                                                                              // anything multipied by its reciprocial gives 1 (a/b + c/d) * (b * d/b * d)                                                    // use the distributive property ( (a/b) * (b * d/b * d) ) +  ( (c/d) * (b * d/b * d) )               (a * b * d) / (b * b * d) + (c * b * d ) / (d * b * d)              //  definition of fraction multiplication (b / b) * ((a * d) / (b * d)) + (d / d) * (c * b) / (b * d)      // komutativity of multiplication just with fractions                                                                                                // and multiplying by a  reciprocial to get multilying by 1 (a * d) / (b * d) + (c * b) / (b * d)                                      // factorize (b * d) which is a common factor ((a * d) + (c * b)) /  (b * d)                                                 // vola and the same goes for subtraction  Thanks for the review XD

@asdasvelet6243  università della Tuscia at Viterbo (In Italy near Rome)

"College level" means regular high school physics. It is algebra based. It has to do with a few factors why they call it that. It would be better to just call it Algebra-based Physics, but college means high school in England and it makes it seem more advanced and better for transcripts in US schools.  There is a level lower called "Concept-based Physics", which is physics with no math. So that would be used in areas that are extremely bad at math.
